Capable of being added. "Addible numbers." Locke.
See Adze. [Obs.] Moxon.
Addicted; devoted. [Obs.]
The quality or state of being addicted; attachment.
The state of being addicted; devotion; inclination. "Hisaddiction was to courses vain." Shak.
An addition, or a thing added. Fuller.My persuasion that the latter verses of the chapter were anadditament of a later age. Coleridge.
That part of arithmetic which treats of adding numbers.
Added; supplemental; in the way of an addition.
By way of addition.
Additional. [R.] Herbert.
Additive. [R.] Sir J. Herschel.
Proper to be added; positive; -- opposed to subtractive.
Tending to add; making some addition. [R.] Arbuthnot.
Having lost the power of development, and become rotten, aseggs; putrid. Hence: Unfruitful or confused, as brains; muddled.Dryden.
Earnings. [Prov. Eng.] Wright.
To adjudge. [Obs.] Spenser.
Set or turned back to back.

To consign or intrust to the care of another, as agent orfactor; as, the ship was addressed to a merchant in Baltimore. Toaddress one's self to. (a) To prepare one's self for; to apply one'sself to. (b) To direct one's speech or discourse to.
One to whom anything is addressed.
The act of addressing or directing one's course. [Rare & Obs.]Chapman.

To bring forward or offer, as an argument, passage, orconsideration which bears on a statement or case; to cite; to allege.Reasons . . . were adduced on both sides. Macaulay.Enough could not be adduced to satisfy the purpose of illustration.De Quincey.
Bringing together or towards a given point; -- a word appliedto those muscles of the body which pull one part towards another.Opposed to abducent.
One who adduces.
Capable of being adduced.Proofs innumerable, and in every imaginable manner diversified, areadducible. I. Taylor.
To draw towards a common center or a middle line. Huxley.
The action by which the parts of the body are drawn towards itsaxis]; -- opposed to abduction. Dunglison.
Adducing, or bringing towards or to something.

A muscle which draws a limb or part of the body toward themiddle line of the body, or closes extended parts of the body; --opposed to abductor; as, the adductor of the eye, which turns the eyetoward the nose.In the bivalve shells, the muscles which close the values of theshell are called adductor muscles. Verrill.
To sweeten; to soothe. [Obs.] Bacon.
To revoke, as a legacy, grant, etc., or to satisfy it by someother gift.
A Spanish red wine made of the first ripe grapes.
A governor of a province; a commander. Prescott.
A provisional name for a plant which has not had its flowersbotanically examined, and therefore has not been referred to itsproper genus.
Same as Atheling.
Applied to sexual zooids of hydroids, that have a saclike formand do not become free; -- opposed to phanerocodonic.
An animal having feet that are not apparent.
A "brotherhood," or collection of stamens in a bundle; -- usedin composition, as in the class names, Monadelphia, Diadelphia, etc.
Having coalescent or clustered filaments; -- said of stamens;as, adelphous stamens. Usually in composition; as, monadelphous.Gray.
Takes away. [Obs.]Without any sinister suspicion of anything being added or adempt.Latimn.
The revocation or taking away of a grant donation, legacy, orthe like. Bouvier.
Shaped like a gland; adenoid. Dunglison.
Glandular inflammation. Dunglison.
Pertaining to adenography.
That part of anatomy which describes the glands.
Pertaining to adenology.
The part of physiology that treats of the glands.
A benign tumor of a glandlike structure; morbid enlargement ofa gland. -- Ad`e*nom"a*tous, a.
Disease of a gland.
Producing glands.
Having glands on the leaves.
The hardening of a gland.
Like a gland; full of glands; glandulous; adenous.
Pertaining to adenotomy.
Dissection of, or incision into, a gland or glands.
Same as Adenose.
Animal fat; lard.
One fully skilled or well versed in anything; a proficient; as,adepts in philosophy.
An obtaining; attainment. [Obs.]In the wit and policy of the capitain consisteth the chief adeptionof the victory. Grafton.
A skilled alchemist. [Obs.]
The quality of being adept; skill.
The state or quality of being adequate, proportionate, orsufficient; a sufficiency for a particular purpose; as, the adequacyof supply to the expenditure.
Equal to some requirement; proportionate, or correspondent;fully sufficient; as, powers adequate to a great work; an adequatedefinition.Ireland had no adequate champion. De Quincey.
In an adequate manner.
The quality of being adequate; suitableness; sufficiency;adequacy.
The act of equalizing; act or result of making adequate; anequivalent. [Obs.] Bp. Barlow.
The division or defective coherence of an organ that is usuallyentire.
One who held the real presence of Christ's body in theeucharist, but not by transubstantiation.
See Affected, 5.
See Affiliated. [Obs.]
See Affiliation. [Obs.]
See Affluxion.
Clinging, as by hooks.
Congenitally united with an organ of another kind, as calyxwith ovary, or stamens with petals.
In an adherent manner.
One who adheres; an adherent.
The molecular attraction exerted between bodies in contact. SeeCohesion.
In an adhesive manner.
Propensity to form and maintain attachments to persons, and topromote social intercourse.
The act of adhibiting; application; use. Whitaker.
To exhort; to advise. [Obs.] Feltham.
Advice; exhortation. [Obs.] Peacham.
Containing counsel or warning; hortatory; advisory. [Obs.]Potter.

Not giving out or receiving heat.-- Ad`i*a*bat`ic*al*ly, adv. Adiabatic line or curve, a curveexhibiting the variations of pressure and volume of a fluid when itexpands without either receiving or giving out heat. Rankine.
Not transmitting the actinic rays.
A genus of ferns, the leaves of which shed water; maidenhair.Also, the black maidenhair, a species of spleenwort.
Religious indifference.
One of the German Protestants who, with Melanchthon, held someopinions and ceremonies to be indifferent or nonessential, whichLuther condemned as sinful or heretical. Murdock.
Pertaining to matters indifferent in faith and practice.Shipley.
Same as Adiaphorist.
Incapable of doing either harm or good, as some medicines.Dunglison.
Indifference. [Obs.]
Not pervious to heat.
Good-by; farewell; an expression of kind wishes at parting.
To set in order; to array; to attire; to deck, to dress. [Obs.]
Adieu; farewell; good-by; -- chiefly used among Spanish-speaking people.
Becoming fatty.
Pertaining to, or derived from, fatty or oily substances; --applied to certain acids obtained from fats by the action of nitricacid.
To convert adipocere.
The act or process of changing into adipocere.

A soft, unctuous, or waxy substance, of a light brown color,into which the fat and muscle tissue of dead bodies sometimes areconverted, by long immersion in water or by burial in moist places.It is a result of fatty degeneration.
Having the form or appearance of adipocere; as, anadipoceriform tumor.
Like adipocere.
Producing fat.
The digestion of fats.
Hydrolyzing fats; converting neutral fats into glycerin andfree fatty acids, esp. by the action of an enzyme; as, adipolyticaction.
A mass of fat found internally; also, a fatty tumor. --Ad`i*pom"a*tous, a.
Of or pertaining to animal fat; fatty. Adipose fin (Zoöl.), asoft boneless fin.-- Adipose tissue (Anat.), that form of animal tissue which forms orcontains fat.
Fatty; adipose. [R.]
Quenching thirst, as certain fruits.
Absence of thirst.
Lying near, close, or contiguous; neighboring; bordering on;as, a field adjacent to the highway. "The adjacent forest." B.Jonson. Adjacent or contiguous angle. (Geom.) See Angle.
So as to be adjacent.
To add or annex; to join. Leland.
The act or mode of adding; also, the thing added. [R.] B.Jonson.
Pertaining to adjection; that is, or may be, annexed. [R.]Earle.
Added; additional. Parkhurst.
Of or relating to the relating to the adjective; of the natureof an adjective; adjective. W. Taylor (1797)
As, or in the manner of, an adjective; adjectively.

A word used with a noun, or substantive, to express a qualityof the thing named, or something attributed to it, or to limit ordefine it, or to specify or describe a thing, as distinct fromsomething else. Thus, in phrase, "a wise ruler," wise is theadjective, expressing a property of ruler.
In the manner of an adjective; as, a word used adjectively.
To join or unite to; to lie contiguous to; to be in contactwith; to attach; to append.Corrections . . . should be, as remarks, adjoined by way of note.Watts.
Contiguous. [Obs.] Carew.
Joining to; contiguous; adjacent; as, an adjoining room. "Theadjoining fane." Dryden.Upon the hills adjoining to the city. Shak.
An adjunct; a helper. [Obs.]

To put off or defer to another day, or indefinitely; topostpone; to close or suspend for the day; -- commonly said of themeeting, or the action, of convened body; as, to adjourn the meeting;to adjourn a debate.It is a common practice to adjourn the reformation of their lives toa further time. Barrow.'Tis a needful fitness That we adjourn this court till further day.Shak.
Adjournment; postponement. [R.] "An adjournal of the Diet." SirW. Scott.
One who adjudges.
The act of adjudging; judicial decision; adjudication. Sir W.Temple.
To adjudge; to try and determine, as a court; to settle byjudicial decree.
The decision upon the question whether the debtor is abankrupt. Abbott.
Adjudicating.
One who adjudicates.
Adjudication.
To yoke to. [Obs.]
Help; support; also, a helper. [Obs.] Waterhouse.
Conjoined; attending; consequent.Though that my death were adjunct to my act. Shak.Adjunct notes (Mus.), short notes between those essential to theharmony; auxiliary notes; passing notes.
The act of joining; the thing joined or added.
Joining; having the quality of joining; forming an adjunct.
In an adjunctive manner.
By way of addition or adjunct; in connection with.
Containing an adjuration.

To charge, bind, or command, solemnly, as if under oath, orunder the penalty of a curse; to appeal to in the most solemn orimpressive manner; to entreat earnestly.Joshua adjured them at that time, saying, Cursed be the man beforethe Lord, that riseth up and buildeth this city Jericho. Josh. vi.26.The high priest . . . said . . . I adjure thee by the living God,that thou tell us whether thou be the Christ. Matt. xxvi. 63.The commissioners adjured them not to let pass so favorable anopportunity of securing their liberties. Marshall.
One who adjures.
Capable of being adjusted.

One who, or that which, adjusts.
Tending to adjust. [R.]
Settlement of claims; an equitable arrangement of conflictingclaims, as in set-off, contribution, exoneration, subrogation, andmarshaling. Bispham.
Same as Ajutage.

A regimental staff officer, who assists the colonel, orcommanding officer of a garrison or regiment, in the details ofregimental and garrison duty. Adjutant general (a) (Mil.), theprincipal staff officer of an army, through whom the commandinggeneral receives communications and issues military orders. In the U.S. army he is brigadier general. (b) (Among the Jesuits), one of aselect number of fathers, who resided with the general of the order,each of whom had a province or country assigned to his care.
A corruption of Agitator.
To add. [Obs.]
A helper or assistant. [Archaic] Drayton.
Serving to help or assist; helping. [Obs.]
A female helper or assistant. [R.]
Helping; helpful; assisting. [R.] "Adjuvant causes." Howell.

A right formerly claimed by the states of the German Empire ofjoining their own ministers with those of the emperor in publictreaties and negotiations to the common interest of the empire.Encyc. Brit.
See Allocution. [Obs.]
To write in the margin. [R.] Coleridge.
Near to the maxilla or jawbone.
To determine the proper share of, or the proper apportionment;as, to admeasure dower; to admeasure common of pasture. Blackstone.
One who admeasures.
Same as Admeasurement.
Corroborative or explanatory proof.
Supplying help; auxiliary; corroborative; explanatory; as,adminicular evidence. H. Spencer.
Adminicular.
To settle, as the estate of one who dies without a will, orwhose will fails of an executor.
Pertaining to administration, or to the executive part ofgovernment.
Capable of being administered; as, an administrable law.
Executive; acting; managing affairs.-- n.
To administer. [R.] Milman.
Pertaining to administration; administering; executive; as, anadministrative body, ability, or energy.-- Ad*min"is*tra`tive*ly, adv.
A man who manages or settles the estate of an intestate, or ofa testator when there is no competent executor; one to whom the rightof administration has been committed by competent authority.
The position or office of an administrator.
A woman who administers; esp., one who administers the estateof an intestate, or to whom letters of administration have beengranted; a female administrator.
Admirableness. [R.] Johnson.
The quality of being admirable; wonderful excellence.
In an admirable manner.

A handsome butterfly (Pyrameis Atalanta) of Europe and America.The larva feeds on nettles. Admiral shell (Zoöl.), the popular nameof an ornamental cone shell (Conus admiralis). Lord High Admiral, agreat officer of state, who (when this rare dignity is conferred) isat the head of the naval administration of Great Britain.
The office or position oaf an admiral; also, the naval skill ofan admiral.
Admiration. [Obs.] Spenser.
Relating to or expressing admiration or wonder. [R.] Earle.
To wonder; to marvel; to be affected with surprise; --sometimes with at.To wonder at Pharaoh, and even admire at myself. Fuller.
One who admires; one who esteems or loves greatly. Cowper.
Expressing admiration; as, an admiring glance.-- Ad*mir"ing*ly, adv. Shak.
The quality of being admissible; admissibleness; as, theadmissibility of evidence.
Entitled to be admitted, or worthy of being admitted; that maybe allowed or conceded; allowable; as, the supposition is hardlyadmissible.-- Ad*mis"si*ble*ness, n.-- Ad*mis"si*bly, adv.

Acquiescence or concurrence in a statement made by another, anddistinguishable from a confession in that an admission presupposesprior inquiry by another, but a confession may be made without suchinquiry.
Implying an admission; tending to admit. [R.] Lamb.
Pertaining to admission.
Admissible. Sir T. Browne.
The act of giving possession of a copyhold estate. Bouvier.
The certificate of admission given in some American colleges.
One who admits.
To mingle with something else; to mix. [R.]
A mingling of different things; admixture. Glanvill.
One who admonishes.
Admonition. [R.] Shak.
Gentle or friendly reproof; counseling against a fault orerror; expression of authoritative advice; friendly caution orwarning.
Admonisher. [Obs.]
Admonitory. [R.] Barrow.-- Ad*mon"i*tive*ly, adv.
Admonisher; monitor.Conscience is at most times a very faithful and prudent admonitor.Shenstone.
Admonitory. [R.] "An admonitorial tone." Dickens.
That conveys admonition; warning or reproving; as, anadmonitory glance.-- Ad*mon"i*to*ri*ly,, adv.
A female admonitor.
The reducing or lands or tenements to mortmain. See Mortmain.
To move or conduct to or toward. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Growing to or on something else. "An adnascent plant." Evelyn.
Grown to congenitally.
The adhesion or cohesion of different floral verticils or setsof organs.
Pertaining to an adnoun; adjectival; attached to a noun. Gibbs.-- Ad*nom"i*nal*ly, adv.
An adjective, or attribute. [R.] Coleridge.
Clouded; obscured. [R.]
An unburnt brick dried in the sun; also used as an adjective,as, an adobe house, in Texas or New Mexico.

The state of growing up from childhood to manhood or womanhood;youth, or the period of life between puberty and maturity, generallyconsidered to be, in the male sex, from fourteen to twenty-one.Sometimes used with reference to the lower animals.
The quality of being adolescent; youthfulness.
Growing; advancing from childhood to maturity.Schools, unless discipline were doubly strong, Detain theiradolescent charge too long. Cowper.
A Hebrew name for God, usually translated in the Old Testamentby the word "Lord".
Pertaining to Adonis; Adonic. "Fair Adonean Venus." Faber.
Relating to Adonis, famed for his beauty.-- n.
A youth beloved by Venus for his beauty. He was killed in thechase by a wild boar.
One who maintains that points of the Hebrew word translated"Jehovah" are really the vowel points of the word "Adonai." SeeJehovist.
To beautify; to dandify.I employed three good hours at least in adjusting and adonozingmyself. Smollett.
Capable of being adopted.
Taken by adoption; taken up as one's own; as, an adopted son,citizen, country, word.-- A*dopt"ed*ly, adv.

A receiver, with two necks, opposite to each other, one ofwhich admits the neck of a retort, and the other is joined to anotherreceiver. It is used in distillations, to give more space to elasticvapors, to increase the length of the neck of a retort, or to unitetwo vessels whose openings have different diameters. [Written alsoadapter.]
One of a sect which maintained that Christ was the Son of Godnot by nature but by adoption.
Adopted. [Obs.]
Pertaining to adoption; made or acquired by adoption; fitted toadopt; as, an adoptive father, an child; an adoptive language.-- A*dopt"ive*ly, adv.
Adorableness.
The quality of being adorable, or worthy of adoration. Johnson.
In an adorable manner.
To adorn. [Obs.]Congealed little drops which do the morn adore. Spenser.
The act of adoring; adoration. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
One who adores; a worshiper; one who admires or loves greatly;an ardent admirer. "An adorer of truth." Clarendon.I profess myself her adorer, not her friend. Shak.
With adoration.

To deck or dress with ornaments; to embellish; to set off toadvantage; to render pleasing or attractive.As a bride adorneth herself with her jewels. Isa. lxi. 10.At church, with meek and unaffected grace, His looks adorned thevenerable place. Goldsmith.
Adornment. [Obs.]
He who, or that which, adorns; a beautifier.
By adorning; decoratively.
An adorning; an ornament; a decoration.
Impregnation by external contact, without intromission.
From a higher to a lower situation; downward; down, to or onthe ground. [Archaic] "Thrice did she sink adown." Spenser.
See Appressed.-- Ad*pressed",, a.
Put in dread; afraid. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Gum tragacanth. Brande & C.
To dread. [Obs.] Sir P. Sidney.
Visited by a dream; -- used in the phrase, To be adreamed, todream. [Obs.]
Suprarenal.
Pertaining to the Adriatic Sea; as, Adrian billows.
Of or pertaining to a sea so named, the northwestern part ofwhich is known as the Gulf of Venice.
Floating at random; in a drifting condition; at the mercy ofwind and waves. Also fig.So on the sea shall be set adrift. Dryden.Were from their daily labor turned adrift. Wordsworth.
In a dripping state; as, leaves all adrip. D. G. Mitchell.
To adopt (a person who is his own master).
A kind of adoption in ancient Rome. See Arrogation.

Dexterous in the use of the hands or in the exercise of themental faculties; exhibiting skill and readiness in avoiding dangeror escaping difficulty; ready in invention or execution; -- appliedto persons and to acts; as, an adroit mechanic, an adroit reply."Adroit in the application of the telescope and quadrant." Horsley."He was adroit in intrigue." Macaulay.
In an adroit manner.
The quality of being adroit; skill and readiness; dexterity.Adroitness was as requisite as courage. Motley.
In a dry or thirsty condition. "A man that is adry." Burton.
Supplemental; additional; adventitious; ascititious."Adscititious evidence." Bowring.-- Ad`sci*ti"tious*ly, adv.
Held to service as attached to the soil; -- said of feudalserfs.
Attached or annexed to the glebe or estate and transferablewith it. Brougham.
Additional signification. [R.] Tooke.
To denote additionally. [R.] Tooke.
See Astrict, and Astriction.
See Astrictory.
See Astringent.
A transparent or translucent variety of common feldspar, ororthoclase, which often shows pearly opalescent reflections; --called by lapidaries moonstone.
To flatter in a servile way. Byron.
Servile flattery; praise in excess, or beyond what is merited.Think'st thou the fiery fever will go out With titles blown fromadulation Shak.

Containing excessive praise or compliment; servilely praising;flattering; as, an adulatory address.A mere rant of adulatory freedom. Burke.
A woman who flatters with servility.
Having arrived at maturity, or to full size and strength;matured; as, an adult person or plant; an adult ape; an adult age.
To commit adultery; to pollute. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
That which is used to adulterate anything.-- a. Adulterating; as, adulterant agents and processes.
To commit adultery. [Obs.]
One who adulterates or corrupts. [R.] Cudworth.
A man who violates his religious covenant. Jer. ix. 2.
A woman who violates her religious engagements. James iv. 4.

Proceeding from adulterous intercourse. Hence: Spurious;without the support of law; illegal.When any particular class of artificers or traders thought proper toact as a corporation without a charter, such were called adulterineguilds. Adam Smith.
To commit adultery. Milton.
In an adulterous manner.
The fine and penalty imposed for the offense of adultery.
The state of being adult.
Giving a faint shadow, or slight resemblance; shadowing forth.

Faintly representing; typical. Carlyle.
A uniting; union. Jer. Taylor.
Curvature inwards; hookedness.The aduncity of the beaks of hawks. Pope.
Curved inwards; hooked.
To burn up. [Obs.] Bacon.
Either of two compounds, a chlorine derivative and brominederivative, of hydroquinone, used as developers.
Having much heat in the constitution and little serum in theblood. [Obs.] Hence: Atrabilious; sallow; gloomy.
Burnt; adust. [Obs.] Howell.
That may be burnt. [Obs.]
Cauterization. Buchanan.

Before in place, or beforehand in time; -- used for advanced;as, an advance guard, or that before the main guard or body of anarmy; advance payment, or that made before it is due; advance proofs,advance sheets, pages of a forthcoming volume, received in advance ofthe time of publication.
Property given, usually by a parent to a child, in advance of afuture distribution.
Tending to advance. [R.]

To give an advantage to; to further; to promote; to benefit; toprofit.The truth is, the archbishop's own stiffness and averseness to complywith the court designs, advantaged his adversaries against him.Fuller.What is a man advantaged, if he gain the whole world, and losehimself, or be cast away Luke ix. 25.To advantage one's self of, to avail one's self of. [Obs.]
Advantageous. [Obs.]

Being of advantage; conferring advantage; gainful; profitable;useful; beneficial; as, an advantageous position; trade isadvantageous to a nation.Advabtageous comparison with any other country. Prescott.You see . . . of what use a good reputation is, and how swift andadvantageous a harbinger it is, wherever one goes. Chesterfield.
Profitably; with advantage.
Profitableness.
To accede, or come (to); to be added to something or become apart of it, though not essential. [R.]Where no act of the will advenes as a coefficient. Coleridge.
Coming from outward causes; superadded. [Obs.]
The period including the four Sundays before Christmas. AdventSunday (Eccl.), the first Sunday in the season of Advent, beingalways the nearest Sunday to the feast of St. Andrew (Now. 30).Shipley.
One of a religious body, embracing several branches, who lookfor the proximate personal coming of Christ; -- called also SecondAdventists. Schaff-Herzog Encyc.
Out of the proper or usual place; as, adventitious buds orroots.
Adventitious. Gray.
Relating to the season of advent. Sanderson.
To try the chance; to take the risk.I would adventure for such merchandise. Shak.
Given to adventure.
Full of risk; adventurous; venturesome.-- Ad*ven"ture*some*ness, n.
A female adventurer; a woman who tries to gain position byequivocal means.

The quality or state of being adventurous; daring;venturesomeness.
A word used to modify the sense of a verb, participle,adjective, or other adverb, and usually placed near it; as, he writeswell; paper extremely white.
Of or pertaining to an adverb; of the nature of an adverb; as,an adverbial phrase or form.
The quality of being adverbial. Earle.

In the manner of an adverb.
A miscellaneous collection of notes, remarks, or selections; acommonplace book; also, commentaries or notes.These parchments are supposed to have been St. Paul's adversaria. Bp.Bull.

One who is turned against another or others with a design tooppose
Expressing contrariety, opposition, or antithesis; as, anadversative conjunction (but, however, yet, etc. ); an adversativeforce.-- Ad*ver"sa*tive*ly, adv.

Attentive; heedful; regardful. Sir M. Hale.-- Ad*vert"ent*ly, adv.

To give notice to; to inform or apprise; to notify; to makeknown; hence, to warn; -- often followed by of before the subject ofinformation; as, to advertise a man of his loss. [Archaic]I will advertise thee what this people shall do. Num. xxiv. 14.
One who, or that which, advertises.

Counseling to perform a specific illegal act. Wharton. Adviceboat, a vessel employed to carry dispatches or to reconnoiter; adispatch boat.-- To take advice. (a) To accept advice. (b) To consult with anotheror others.
The quality of being advisable; advisableness.
With advice; wisely.
Deliberate consideration; prudent procedure; caution.

Having power to advise; containing advice; as, an advisorycouncil; their opinion is merely advisory.The General Association has a general advisory superintendence overall the ministers and churches. Trumbull.
The act of pleading for or supporting; work of advocating;intercession.

To plead in favor of; to defend by argument, before a tribunalor the public; to support, vindicate, or recommend publicly.To advocate the cause of thy client. Bp. Sanderson (1624).This is the only thing distinct and sensible, that has beenadvocated. Burke.Eminent orators were engaged to advocate his cause. Mitford.

The right of presenting to a vacant benefice or living in thechurch. [Originally, the relation of a patron (advocatus) orprotector of a benefice, and thus privileged to nominate or presentto it.]
See Avoyer. [Obs.]
Award. [Obs.] Spenser.
Considerable debility of the vital powers, as in typhoid fever.Dunglison.
Pertaining to, or characterized by, debility of the vitalpowers; weak.
Adynamia. [R.] Morin.
The innermost sanctuary or shrine in ancient temples, whenceoracles were given. Hence: A private chamber; a sanctum.
To cut with an adz. [R.] Carlyle.

A diphthong in the Latin language; used also by the Saxonwriters. It answers to the Gr. æ was generally replaced by a, thelong e or ee. In derivatives from Latin words with ae, it is mostlysuperseded by e. For most words found with this initial combination,the reader will therefore search under the letter E.
A form of fruit in the cycle of development of the Rusts orBrands, an order of fungi, formerly considered independent plants.
A magistrate in ancient Rome, who had the superintendence ofpublic buildings, highways, shows, etc.; hence, a municipal officer.
The office of an ædile. T. Arnold.
Of or pertaining to the sea, or arm of the Mediterranean sea,east of Greece. See Archipelago.
Sculptured ornaments, used in classical architecture,representing rams' heads or skulls.
An ulcer or fistula in the inner corner of the eye.
A shield or protective armor; -- applied in mythology to theshield of Jupiter which he gave to Minerva. Also fig.: A shield; aprotection.
Same as Egophony.
A medical certificate that a student is ill.
The great epic poem of Virgil, of which the hero is Æneas.
Colored like bronze.
Æolian, 1; as, the Æolic dialect; the Æolic mode.
Exhibiting differences of quality or property in differentdirections; not isotropic. Sir W. Thomson.
Difference of quality or property in different directions.
The god of the winds.
A period of immeasurable duration; also, an emanation of theDeity. See Eon.
Eternal; everlasting. "Æonian hills." Tennyson.
A gigantic bird found fossil in Madagascar.

To expose to the chemical action of air; to oxygenate (theblood) by respiration; to arterialize. Aërated bread, bread raised bycharging dough with carbonic acid gas, instead of generating the gasin the dough by fermentation.
A change produced in the blood by exposure to the air inrespiration; oxygenation of the blood in respiration;arterialization.
That which supplies with air; esp. an apparatus used forcharging mineral waters with gas and in making soda water.
The state of being aërial; [R.] De Quincey.
Like, or from, the air; in an aërial manner. "A murmur heardaërially." Tennyson.
The nest of a bird of prey, as of an eagle or hawk; also abrood of such birds; eyrie. Shak. Also fig.: A human residence orresting place perched like an eagle's nest.
Conveying or containing air; air-bearing; as, the windpipe isan aëriferous tube.
Having the form or nature of air, or of an elastic fluid;gaseous. Hence fig.: Unreal.
Growing or thriving only in the presence of oxygen; also,pertaining to, or induced by, aërobies; as, aërobic fermentation. --A`ër*o"bic*al*ly (#), adv.
Microörganisms which live in contact with the air and needoxygen for their growth; as the microbacteria which form on thesurface of putrefactive fluids.
Related to, or of the nature of, aërobies; as, aërobioticplants, which live only when supplied with free oxygen.
A form of hydro-aëroplane; a flying boat.
An aëroplane or airship designed to carry passengers.
A club or association of persons interested in aëronautics.
A modification of the aëroplane, having curved surfaces, theadvantages of which were first demonstrated by Lilienthal.
One of the air cells of algals.
The science of gliding and soaring flight.
Pertaining to the force of air in motion.
The science which treats of the air and other gaseous bodiesunder the action of force, and of their mechanical effects.
A plane or arched surface for sustaining bodies by its movementthrough the air; a spread wing, as of a bird.
The science which treats of the properties of the air, and ofthe part it plays in nature. Craig.
One versed in aëography: an aërologist.
A description of the air or atmosphere; aërology.
A cannon capable of being trained at very high angles for useagainst aircraft.
Acting by the force of air and water; as, an aërohydrodynamicwheel.
A stone, or metallic mass, which has fallen to the earth fromdistant space; a meteorite; a meteoric stone.
Same as A.
The science of aërolites.
Of or pertaining to aërolites; meteoric; as, aërolitic iron.Booth.
One versed in aërology.
That department of physics which treats of the atmosphere.
Divination from the state of the air or from atmosphericsubstances; also, forecasting changes in the weather.
A mechanic or mechanician expert in the art and practice ofaëronautics.
The science of equilibrium and motion of air or an aëriformfluid, including aërodynamics and aërostatics.
An instrument for ascertaining the weight or density of air andgases.
Of or pertaining to aërometry; as, aërometric investigations.
The science of measuring the air, including the doctrine of itspressure, elasticity, rarefaction, and condensation; pneumatics.
A dirigible balloon.
An aërial navigator; a balloonist.
The science or art of ascending and sailing in the air, as bymeans of a balloon; aërial navigation; ballooning.
A power-driven, heavier-than-air flying machine.
A plant growing entirely in the air, and receiving itsnourishment from it; an air plant or epiphyte.
A flying machine, or a small plane for experiments on flying,which floats in the air only when propelled through it.
One who flies in an aëroplane.
An apparatus designed for collecting spores, germs, bacteria,etc., suspended in the air.
The observation of the state and variations of the atmosphere.
Of the nature of, or like, copper; brassy. [R.]
A mass of meteoric iron.
The atmosphere. [R.]
The science that treats of the equilibrium of elastic fluids,or that of bodies sustained in them. Hence it includes aëronautics.
The positive or negative stimulus exerted by oxygen on aërobicand anaërobic bacteria. -- A`ër*o*tac"tic (#), a.
Treatment of disease by the use of air or other gases.
A form of hydro-aëroplane; a flying boat.
Of the nature or color of verdigris, or the rust of copper.
The rust of any metal, esp. of brass or copper; verdigris.
An aerie.
Pertaining to Æsculapius or to the healing art; medical;medicinal.
The god of medicine. Hence, a physician.
Same as Esculin.
In the old Norse mythology, the gods Odin, Thor, Loki, Balder,Frigg, and the others. Their home was called Asgard.
Perception by the senses; feeling; -- the opposite ofanæsthesia.
Sensuous perception. [R.] Ruskin.
Conveying sensory or afferent impulses; -- said of nerves.
One who makes much or overmuch of æsthetics. [Recent]
One versed in æsthetics.
The doctrine of æsthetics; æsthetic principles; devotion to thebeautiful in nature and art. Lowell.
Of or belonging to the summer; as, æstival diseases. [Speltalso estival.]
To pass the summer in a state of torpor. [Spelt also estivate.]
The state of torpidity induced by the heat and dryness ofsummer, as in certain snails; -- opposed to hibernation.
See Estuary.
Glowing; agitated, as with heat.
Propagated in an unusual way; cryptogamous.
See Ether.
A compound of nitrogen and boro
An instrument consisting in part of a differential thermometer.It is used for measuring changes of temperature produced by differentconditions of the sky, as when clear or clouded.
Pertaining to ætiology; assigning a cause.-- Æ`ti*o*log"ic*al*ly, adv.
See Eaglestone.
At, to, or from a great distance; far away; -- often used withfrom preceding, or off following; as, he was seen from afar; I sawhim afar off.The steep where Fame's proud temple shines afar. Beattie.
Afraid. [Obs.]Be not afeard; the isle is full of noises. Shak.
The southwest wind. Milton.
The quality of being affable; readiness to converse;courteousness in receiving others and in conversation; complaisantbehavior.Affability is of a wonderful efficacy or power in procuring love.Elyot
Affability.
In an affable manner; courteously.
Executed in a workmanlike manner; ingeniously made. [R.]Bailey.
An action or engagement not of sufficient magnitude to becalled a battle.
To afflict with, or perish from, hunger. [Obs.] Spenser.
Starvation. Bp. Hall.
To infatuate. [Obs.] Milton.
To frighten. [Obs.] Spenser.
Affection; inclination; passion; feeling; disposition. [Obs.]Shak.
One who exhibits affectation. [R.] Fitzed. Hall.
Made up of terms involving different powers of the unknownquantity; adfected; as, an affected equation.
Affectation.
One who affects, assumes, pretends, or strives after."Affecters of wit." Abp. Secker.
The quality or state of being affectible. [R.]
That may be affected. [R.]Lay aside the absolute, and, by union with the creaturely, becomeaffectible. Coleridge.
In an affecting manner; is a manner to excite emotions.
Disease; morbid symptom; malady; as, a pulmonary affection.Dunglison.
Of or pertaining to the affections; as, affectional impulses;an affectional nature.
Disposed; inclined. [Obs.]Affectionated to the people. Holinshed.
With affection; lovingly; fondly; tenderly; kindly.
The quality of being affectionate; fondness; affection.
In an affective manner; impressively; emotionally.
Full of passion or emotion; earnest. [Obs.] --Af*fec"tu*ous*ly, adv. [Obs.] Fabyan.
To assess or reduce, as an arbitrary penalty or amercement, toa certain and reasonable sum.Amercements . . . were affeered by the judges. Blackstone.

Bearing or conducting inwards to a part or organ; -- opposed toefferent; as, afferent vessels; afferent nerves, which conveysensations from the external organs to the brain.
With feeling.

One who makes an affidavit. [U. S.] Burrill.
A written or printed notice to be posted, as on a wall; aposter; a placard.
A sworn statement in writing; a declaration in writing, signedand made upon oath before an authorized magistrate. Bouvier. Burrill.
To polish. [Obs.]
Capable of being affiliated to or on, or connected with inorigin.
To connect or associate one's self; -- followed by with; as,they affiliate with no party.
The establishment or ascertaining of parentage; the assignmentof a child, as a bastard, to its father; filiation.
Related by marriage; from the same source.
To refine. [Obs.] Holland.
Joined in affinity or by any tie. [Obs.] "All affined and kin."Shak.
Of the nature of affinity.-- Af*fin"i*ta*tive*ly, adv.
Closely connected, as by affinity.

That attraction which takes place, at an insensible distance,between the heterogeneous particles of bodies, and unites them toform chemical compounds; chemism; chemical or elective affinity orattraction.
to assert or confirm, as a judgment, decree, or order, broughtbefore an appelate court for review.
Capable of being affirmed, asserted, or declared; -- followedby of; as, an attribute affirmable of every just man.

A solemn declaration made under the penalties of perjury, bypersons who conscientiously decline taking an oath, which declarationis in law equivalent to an oath. Bouvier.
Expressing the agreement of the two terms of a proposition.
In an affirmative manner; on the affirmative side of aquestion; in the affirmative; -- opposed to negatively.
Giving affirmation; assertive; affirmative. Massey.
One who affirms.
That which is affixed; an appendage; esp. one or more lettersor syllables added at the end of a word; a suffix; a postfix.

The act of affixing, or the state of being affixed; attachment.
A blowing or breathing on; inspiration.
Afflicted. [Obs.] Becon.

One who afflicts.
Grievously painful; distressing; afflictive; as, an afflictingevent.-- Af*flict"ing*ly, adv.
Free from affliction.
Giving pain; causing continued or repeated pain or grief;distressing. "Jove's afflictive hand." Pope.Spreads slow disease, and darts afflictive pain. Prior.

Abundantly; copiously.

Asphodel. [Obs.]
To reënforce; to strengthen. Hallam.

That may be afforded.
Anything given as a help; bestowal. [Obs.]
To convert into a forest; as, to afforest a tract of country.
The act of converting into forest or woodland. Blackstone.
An affix.
To make free; to enfranchise. Johnson.
The act of making free; enfranchisement. [R.]
To strike, or strike down. [Obs.] Spenser.
The fighting of two or more persons, in a public place, to theterror of others. Blackstone.
One engaged in an affray.
Affray. [Obs.] Spenser.
To hire, as a ship, for the transportation of goods or freight.

The act of hiring, or the contract for the use of, a vessel, orsome part of it, to convey cargo.

A combination of a stop, or explosive, with an immediatelyfollowing fricative or spirant of corresponding organic position, aspf in german Pfeffer, pepper, z (= ts) in German Zeit, time.

To impress with sudden fear; to frighten; to alarm.Dreams affright our souls. Shak.A drear and dying sound Affrights the flamens at their servicequaint. Milton.

Terrifying; frightful.-- Af*fright"ful*ly, adv. [Archaic]Bugbears or affrightful apparitions. Cudworth.

Face to face, or front to front; facing.
Shamelessly. [Obs.] Bacon.

One who affronts, or insults to the face.
In an affronting manner.
Tending to affront or offend; offensive; abusive.How affrontive it is to despise mercy. South.
The quality that gives an affront or offense. [R.] Bailey.
To pour out or upon. [R.]I first affused water upon the compressed beans. Boyle.
The act of pouring upon, or sprinkling with a liquid, as waterupon a child in baptism. Specifically: (Med)
To trust or confide. [Obs.] Shak.
Of or pertaining to Afghanistan.
On fire.
Inflames; glowing with light or passion; ablaze. G. Eliot.
Level with the ground; flat. [Obs.] Bacon.
In a flaunting state or position. Copley.
In a flickering state.
Flowing.Their founts aflow with tears. R. Browning.
In a flushed or blushing state.
In a flutter; agitated.
In a foaming state; as, the sea is all afoam.
In the fore part of a vessel.
Named or quoted before.
Going before; foregoing.
Beforehand; in anticipation. [Archaic or Dial.]She is come aforehand to anoint my body. Mark xiv. 8.
Previously mentioned; before-mentioned. Addison.
Named before. Peacham.
Said before, or in a preceding part; already described oridentified.
Premeditated; prepense; previously in mind; designed; as,malice aforethought, which is required to constitute murder. Bouvier.
In time past; formerly. "He prayed . . . as he did aforetime."Dan. vi. 10.
In collision; entangled. Totten. To run afoul of, to runagainst or come into collision with, especially so as to becomeentangled or to cause injury.
Impressed with fear or apprehension; in fear; apprehensive.[Afraid comes after the noun it limits.] "Back they recoiled,afraid." Milton.
Same as Afrit.
Anew; again; once more; newly.They crucify . . . the Son of God afresh. Heb. vi. 6.
African.-- n.

Of or pertaining to Africa. African hemp, a fiber prerared fromthe leaves of the Sanseviera Guineensis, a plant found in Africa andIndia.-- African marigold, a tropical American plant (Tagetes erecta).-- African oak or African teak, a timber furnished by OldfieldiaAfricana, used in ship building. African violet African-American, aUnited States citizen of African descent.
One born in Africa, the offspring of a white father and a"colored" mother. Also, and now commonly in Southern Africa, a nativeborn of European settlers.
A word, phrase, idiom, or custom peculiar to Africa orAfricans. "The knotty Africanisms . . . of the fathers." Milton.
To place under the domination of Africans or negroes. [Amer.]Bartlett.
In front; face to face.-- prep. In front of. Shak.
Near or towards the stern of a vessel; astern; abaft.
To ward the stern of the ship; -- applied to any object in therear part of a vessel; as the after cabin, after hatchway.
The placenta and membranes with which the fetus is connected,and which come away after delivery.
A throw of dice after the game in ended; hence, anything donetoo late. Gower.
An unexpected subsequent event; something disagreeablehappening after an affair is supposed to be at an end. Spenser.
A second crop or harvest in the same year. Mortimer.
To look after. [Poetic] Shak.
A second game; hence, a subsequent scheme or expedient. Wotton.Aftergame at Irish, an ancient game very nearly resemblingbackgammon. Beau. & Fl.
The grass that grows after the first crop has been mown;aftermath.
A second growth or crop, or (metaphorically) development. J. S.Mill.
The seaman or seamen stationed on the poop or after part of theship, to attend the after-sails. Totten.
The last milk drawn in milking; strokings. [Obs.] Grose.
A second moving; the grass which grows after the first crop ofhay in the same season; rowen. Holland.
Nearest the stern; most aft.
The part of the day which follows noon, between noon andevening.
The pains which succeed childbirth, as in expelling theafterbirth.
The heel of a rudder.

A sensation or sense impression following the removal of astimulus producing a primary sensation, and reproducing the primarysensation in positive, negative, or complementary form. Theaftersensation may be continuous with the primary sensation or followit after an interval.
The hypoptilum.
A taste which remains in the mouth after eating or drinking.
Reflection after an act; later or subsequent thought orexpedient.
Wise after the event; wise or knowing, when it is too late.
Nearest the stern.
Toward the stern.
Against; also, towards (in order to meet). [Obs.]Albeit that it is again his kind. Chaucer.
To redeem. [Obs.] Wyclif.
To gainsay. [Obs.] Wyclif.
To withstand. [Obs.]
Back again. [Obs.]
Lacking milk to suckle with.
A soft, compact stone, of a grayish, greenish, or yellowishcolor, carved into images by the Chinese, and hence called figurestone, and pagodite. It is probably a variety of pinite.
A genus of lizards, one of the few which feed upon vegetablesubstances; also, one of these lizards.
A South American bird (Psophia crepitans), allied to thecranes, and easily domesticated; -- called also the gold-breastedtrumpeter. Its body is about the size of the pheasant. See Trumpeter.
In an agamic manner.
An unmarried person; also, one opposed to marriage. Foxe.
Reproduction without the union of parents of distinct sexes:asexual reproduction.
Reproducing or produced without sexual union.-- Ag`a*mo*ge*net"ic*al*ly, adv.All known agamogenetic processes end in a complete return to theprimitive stock. Huxley.
Having no visible sexual organs; asexual. In Bot.,cryptogamous.
Without ganglia.
Gaping, as with wonder, expectation, or eager attention.Dazzles the crowd and sets them all agape. Milton.
A fungus of the genus Agaricus, of many species, of which thecommon mushroom is an example.
In a state of gasping. Coleridge.
See Aghast.
Having to stomach, or distinct digestive canal, as thetapeworm.
On the way; agoing; as, to be agate; to set the bells agate.[Obs.] Cotgrave.
Containing or producing agates. Craig.
Pertaining to, or like, agate.
To convert into agate; to make resemble agate. Dana.
Of the nature of agate, or containing agate.

A genus of plants (order Amaryllidaceæ) of which the chiefspecies is the maguey or century plant (A. Americana), wrongly calledAloe. It is from ten to seventy years, according to climate, inattaining maturity, when it produces a gigantic flower stem,sometimes forty feet in height, and perishes. The fermented juice isthe pulque of the Mexicans; distilled, it yields mescal. A strongthread and a tough paper are made from the leaves, and the wood hasmany uses.
Gazing with astonishment; amazed. [Obs.]The whole army stood agazed on him. Shak.

To grow aged; to become old; to show marks of age; as, he grewfat as he aged.They live one hundred and thirty years, and never age for all that.Holland.I am aging; that is, I have a whitish, or rather a light-colored,hair here and there. Landor.
In the manner of an aged person.
The quality of being aged; oldness.Custom without truth is but agedness of error. Milton.
Without old age limits of duration; as, fountains of agelessyouth.
See Again. [Obs.]
See Agendum. [Obs.]
Characterized by sterility; infecund.
Any imperfect development of the body, or any anomaly oforganization.
Impotence; sterility.
Actingpatient, or sustaining, action. [Archaic] "The bodyagent." Bacon.
Of or pertaining to an agent or an agency. Fitzed. Hall.
Agency. Beau. & Fl.
A genus of plants, one species of which (A. Mexicanum) haslavender-blue flowers in dense clusters.
The act of producing in addition. [Obs.] T. Stanley.
An earthwork; a mound; a raised work. [Obs.] Hearne.
To heap up. [Obs.] Foxe.
A heaping up; accumulation; as, aggerations of sand. [R.]
In heaps; full of heaps.
To heap up. [Obs.]The violence of the waters aggested the earth. Fuller.
To wind or collect into a ball; hence, to gather into a mass oranything like a mass.Where he builds the agglomerated pile. Cowper.
Having a tendency to gather together, or to make collections.Taylor is eminently discursive, accumulative, and (to use one of hisown words) agglomerative. Coleridge.
Uniting, as glue; causing, or tending to cause, adhesion.-- n.
To unite, or cause to adhere, as with glue or other viscoussubstance; to unite by causing an adhesion of substances.
Combination in which root words are united with little or nochange of form or loss of meaning. See Agglutinative, 2.

Formed or characterized by agglutination, as a language or acompound.In agglutinative languages the union of words may be compared tomechanical compounds, in inflective languages to chemical compounds.R. Morris.Cf. man-kind, heir-loom, war-like, which are agglutinative compounds.The Finnish, Hungarian, Turkish, the Tamul, etc., are agglutinativelanguages. R. Morris.Agglutinative languages preserve the consciousness of their roots.Max Müller.
To favor; to grace. [Obs.] "That knight so much aggraced."Spenser.
To bring, or tend to bring, to a uniform grade, or slope, byaddition of material; as, streams aggrade their beds by depositingsediment.
Capable of being aggrandized.
Aggrandizement. [Obs.] Waterhouse.
To increase or become great. [Obs.]Follies, continued till old age, do aggrandize. J. Hall.
The act of aggrandizing, or the state of being aggrandized orexalted in power, rank, honor, or wealth; exaltation; enlargement;as, the emperor seeks only the aggrandizement of his own family.
One who aggrandizes, or makes great.
To please. [Obs.]Each one sought his lady to aggrate. Spenser.
In an aggravating manner.
Tending to aggravate. Ag*gres"sive*ly, adv.-- Ag*gres"sive*ness, n.No aggressive movement was made. Macaulay.
Collectively; in mass.
The act of aggregating, or the state of being aggregated;collection into a mass or sum; a collection of particulars; anaggregate.
One who aggregates.
To make heavy; to aggravate. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To commit the first act of hostility or offense; to begin aquarrel or controversy; to make an attack; -- with on.
The first attack, or act of hostility; the first act of injury,or first act leading to a war or a controversy; unprovoked attack;assault; as, a war of aggression. "Aggressions of power."  Hallam
Tending or disposed to aggress; characterized by aggression;making assaults; unjustly attacking; as, an aggressive policy, war,person, nation. -- Ag*gres"sive*ly, adv. -- Ag*gres"sive*ness, n.
The person who first attacks or makes an aggression; he whobegins hostility or a quarrel; an assailant.The insolence of the aggressor is usually proportioned to thetameness of the sufferer. Ames.
Oppression; hardship; injury; grievance. [Archaic]

To give pain or sorrow to; to afflict; hence, to oppress orinjure in one's rights; to bear heavily upon; -- now commonly used inthe passive TO be aggrieved.Aggrieved by oppression and extortion. Macaulay.
To bring together in a group; to group. Dryden.
Arrangement in a group or in groups; grouping.
See Agast, v. t. [Obs.]
Possible to be done; practicable. [Obs.] "Fit for agiblethings." Sir A. Sherley.
Having the faculty of quick motion in the limbs; apt or readyto move; nimble; active; as, an agile boy; an agile tongue.Shaking it with agile hand. Cowper.
In an agile manner; nimbly.
Agility; nimbleness. [R.]
The premium or percentage on a better sort of money when it isgiven in exchange for an inferior sort. The premium or discount onforeign bills of exchange is sometimes called agio.
Exchange business; also, stockjobbing; the maneuvers ofspeculators to raise or lower the price of stocks or public funds.Vanity and agiotage are to a Parisian the oxygen and hydrogen oflife. Landor.
To take to graze or pasture, at a certain sum; -- usedoriginally of the feeding of cattle in the king's forests, andcollecting the money for the same. Blackstone.
See Agister.
Capable of being agitated, or easily moved. [R.]
In an agitated manner.
Tending to agitate.
Sung or played in a restless, hurried, and spasmodic manner.
One of a body of men appointed by the army, in Cromwell's time,to look after their interests; -- called also adjutators. Clarendon.
Gleaming; as, faces agleam. Lowell.
Aside; askew. [Scotch] Burns.
In a glimmering state. Hawthorne.
Clittering; in a glitter.
Without tongue; tongueless.
In a glow; glowing; as, cheeks aglow; the landscape all aglow.
Inability to swallow.
Pertaining to an army marching, or to a train. [R.]
A relative whose relationship can be traced exclusively throughmales.
Pertaining to descent by the male line of ancestors. "Theagnatic succession." Blackstone.
Consanguinity by a line of males only, as distinguished fromcognation. Bouvier.
Acknowledgment. [Obs.] Grafton.
To recognize; to acknowledge. [Archaic]I do agnize a natural and prompt alacrity. Shak.
The doctrine concerning those things of which we arenecessarily ignorant.
To name. [Obs.]
Professing ignorance; involving no dogmatic; pertaining to orinvolving agnosticism.-- Ag*nos"tic*al*ly, adv.
That doctrine which, professing ignorance, neither asserts nordenies. Specifically: (Theol.)
Agnus Dei.
Past; gone by; since; as, ten years ago; gone long ago.
In eager desire; eager; astir.All agog to dash through thick and thin. Cowper.
In motion; in the act of going; as, to set a mill agoing.
A contest for a prize at the public games.
Ago. [Archaic. & Poet.]Three days agone I fell sick. 1 Sam. xxx. 13.

Not forming an angle. Agonic line (Physics), an imaginary lineon the earth's surface passing through those places where themagnetic needle points to the true north; the line of no magneticvariation. There is one such line in the Western hemisphere, andanother in the Eastern hemisphere.
Contention for a prize; a contest. [Obs.] Blount.
One who contends for the prize in public games. [R.]
In an agonistic manner.
The science of athletic combats, or contests in public games.
To cause to suffer agony; to subject to extreme pain; totorture.He agonized his mother by his behavior. Thackeray.
With extreme anguish or desperate struggles.
An officer who presided over the great public games in Greece.
Pertaining to the office of an agonothete.
In earnest; heartily. [Obs.] "I made her weep agood."  Shak.
An assembly; hence, the place of assembly, especially themarket place, in an ancient Greek city.
The crab-eating raccoon (Procyon cancrivorus), found in thetropical parts of America.
A small insectivorous mammal (Solenodon paradoxus), allied tothe moles, found only in Hayti.
See Aggrace. [Obs.]
A illiterate person. [Obs.] Bailey.
The absence or loss of the power of expressing ideas by writtensigns. It is one form of aphasia.
Characterized by agraphia.
Hooks and eyes for armor, etc. Fairholt.
Wild; -- said of plants growing in the fields.
An equal or equitable division of landed property; theprinciples or acts of those who favor a redistribution of land.
To distribute according to, or to imbue with, the principles ofagrarianism.
To correspond in gender, number, case, or person.
In an agreeing manner (to); correspondingly; agreeably. [Obs.]
Concord or correspondence of one word with another in gender,number, case, or person.
One who agrees.
Pertaining to fields or the country, in opposition to the city;rural; rustic; unpolished; uncouth. "Agrestic behavior." Gregory.
Agrestic. [Obs.]
Agriculture. [Obs.] Bailey.
A cultivator of the soil; an agriculturist. Dodsley.
An agriculturist; a farmer. [R.]

Of or pertaining to agriculture; connected with, or engaged in,tillage; as, the agricultural class; agricultural implements, wages,etc.-- Ag`ri*cul"tur*al*ly, adv. Agricultural ant (Zoöl.), a species ofant which gathers and stores seeds of grasses, for food. Theremarkable species (Myrmica barbata) found in Texas clears circularareas and carefully cultivates its favorite grain, known as ant rice.
An agriculturist (which is the preferred form.)
The art or science of cultivating the ground, including theharvesting of crops, and the rearing and management of live stock;tillage; husbandry; farming.
Agriculture. [R.]
One engaged or skilled in agriculture; a husbandman.The farmer is always a practitioner, the agriculturist may be a meretheorist. Crabb.
In grief; amiss. [Obs.] Chaucer.
In the act of grinning. "His visage all agrin." Tennyson.
One versed or engaged in agriology.
Description or comparative study of the customs of savage oruncivilized tribes.
To shudder with terror; to tremble with fear. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A disease occurring in Bengal and other parts of the EastIndies, in which the tongue chaps and cleaves.
The science of the distribution and management of land.
One versed in agronomy; a student of agronomy.
The management of land; rural economy; agriculture.
In the act of groping. Mrs. Browning.
A genus of grasses, including species called in common languagebent grass. Some of them, as redtop (Agrostis vulgaris), are valuablepasture grasses.
A description of the grasses.
One skilled in agrostology.
That part of botany which treats of the grasses.
That branch of agriculture dealing with the methods ofconversion of agricultural products into manufactured articles;agricultural technology.
On the ground; stranded; -- a nautical term applied to a shipwhen its bottom lodges on the ground. Totten.
See Aggroupment.
Anything which prevents sleep, or produces wakefulness, asstrong tea or coffee.
An intermittent fever, attended by alternate cold and hot fits.
To be guilty of; to offend; to sin against; to wrong. [Obs.]Chaucer.
Dress. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.
In a gushing state. Hawthorne.
Without female organs; male.
An exclamation, expressive of surprise, pity, complaint,entreaty, contempt, threatening, delight, triumph, etc., according tothe manner of utterance.
An exclamation expressing, by different intonations, triumph,mixed with derision or irony, or simple surprise.
In a heap; huddled together. Hood.
Aloft; on high. [Obs.] "Look up aheight." Shak.
An exclamation to call one's attention; hem.
Hey; ho.
On high. [Obs.] Shak.
Near the wind; as, to lay a ship ahold. [Obs.] Shak.
On horseback.Two suspicious fellows ahorseback. Smollet.
A term used in hailing; as, "Ship ahoy."
The Evil Principle or Being of the ancient Persians; the Princeof Darkness as opposer to Ormuzd, the King of Light.
The Asiatic gazelle.
With the sails furled, and the helm lashed alee; -- applied toships in a storm. See Hull, n.
Pinched with hunger; very hungry. C. Bronté.
The three-toed sloth (Bradypus tridactylus) of South America.See Sloth.

To support, either by furnishing strength or means incoöperation to effect a purpose, or to prevent or to remove evil; tohelp; to assist.You speedy helpers . . . Appear and aid me in this enterprise. Shak.
Aid. [R.]Aidance 'gainst the enemy. Shak.
Helping; helpful; supplying aid. Shak.
One who, or that which, aids.
Helpful. [Archaic.] Bp. Hall.
Helpless; without aid. Milton.
See Ayle. [Obs.]
Same as Aglet.
Sour. [Obs.] Shak.
Charcoal prepared for making powder.
See Aglet. Spenser.

To affect with pain or uneasiness, either physical or mental;to trouble; to be the matter with; -- used to express some uneasinessor affection, whose cause is unknown; as, what ails the man I knownot what ails him.What aileth thee, Hagar Gen. xxi. 17.
Same as Ailantus.
A genus of beautiful trees, natives of the East Indies. Thetree imperfectly di
A half gable, as at the end of a penthouse or of the aisle of achurch.
A small square shield, formerly worn on the shoulders ofknights, -- being the prototype of the modern epaulet. Fairholt.
Indisposition; morbid affection of the body; -- not appliedordinarily to acute diseases. "Little ailments." Landsdowne.
A group of the Carnivora, which includes the cats, civets, andhyenas.

To direct or point, as a weapon, at a particular object; todirect, as a missile, an act, or a proceeding, at, to, or against anobject; as, to aim a musket or an arrow, the fist or a blow (atsomething); to aim a satire or a reflection (at some person or vice).
One who aims, directs, or points.
Without aim or purpose; as, an aimless life.-- Aim"less*ly, adv.-- Aim"less*ness, n.

One of a peculiar race inhabiting Yesso, the Kooril Islandsetc., in the northern part of the empire of Japan, by some supposedto have been the progenitors of the Japanese. The Ainos are stout andshort, with hairy bodies.
An artificial or affected manner; show of pride or vanity;haughtiness; as, it is said of a person, he puts on airs. Thackeray.
Any device, as a balloon, aëroplane, etc., for floating in, orflying through, the air.
In an airy manner; lightly; gaily; jauntily; fippantly.
Not open to a free current of air; wanting fresh air, orcommunication with the open air.
Resembling air.
A thoughtless, gay person. [Obs.] "Slight airlings." B. Jonson.
A man who ascends or flies in an aircraft; a flying machinepilot.
Art, skill, or ability in the practice of aërial navigation.
A grayish green antiseptic powder, consisting of a basic iodideand gallate of bismuth, sometimes used in place of iodoform. [ATrademark]
A hollow cylinder to contain air. It is closed above and openbelow, and has its open end plunged into water.
Affected with aërial sickness. -- Air"sick`ness, n.
A woman who ascends or flies in an aircraft.
Having the light and aërial tints true to nature. Elmes.
Furnished with an aisle or aisles.
Without an aisle.
An islet, or little isle, in a river or lake; an eyot.The ait where the osiers grew. R. Hodges (1649).Among green aits and meadows. Dickens.
The letter h or H.
The bone of the rump; also, the cut of beef surrounding thisbone. [Spelt also edgebone.]
See Ætiology.
Slightly turned or opened; as, the door was standing ajar.
See Ajouan.
On the jog.
A tube through which is water is discharged; an efflux tube;as, the ajutage of a fountain.
See Ache.
Same as Achene.
See Acton.
With a crook or bend; with the hand on the hip and elbow turnedoutward. "With one arm akimbo." Irving.
Paralysis of the motor nerves; loss of movement. Foster.
Pertaining to akinesia.
On the knee. [R.] Southey.
Earlier form of Acknow. [Obs.] To be aknow, to acknowledge; toconfess. [Obs.]
All. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A winglike organ, or part.
Alabastrine.
Of, pertaining to, or like, alabaster; as alabastrine limbs.
A flower bud. Gray.
An exclamation expressive of sorrow. [Archaic. or Poet.] Shak.
An exclamation expressing sorrow.
To rouse to action; to inspirit.
Brisk; joyously active; lively.'T were well if we were a little more alacrious. Hammond.
With alacrity; briskly.
Alacrity. [Obs.] Hammond.

A cheerful readiness, willingness, or promptitude; joyousactivity; briskness; sprightliness; as, the soldiers advanced withalacrity to meet the enemy.I have not that alacrity of spirit, Nor cheer of mind that I was wontto have. Shak.
One of a sect of freethinkers among the Mohammedans.
Inability to utter articulate sounds, due either to paralysisof the larynx or to that form of aphasia, called motor, or ataxis,aphasia, due to loss of control of the muscles of speech.
The lowest note but one in Guido Aretino's scale of music.
The quality of being à la mode; conformity to the mode orfashion; fashionableness. [R.] Southey.
According to the fashion or prevailing mode. "Alamode beefshops." Macaulay.
To the death; mortally.
A wolfhound. [Obs.] Chaucer.
On land; to the land; ashore. "Cast aland." Sir P. Sidney.
A white crystalline base, C3H7NO2, derived from aldehydeammonia.
See Inulin.
Axillary; in the fork or axil. Gray.
Easily alarmed or disturbed.
Aroused to vigilance; excited by fear of approaching danger;agitated; disturbed; as, an alarmed neighborhood; an alarmed modesty.The white pavilions rose and fell On the alarmed air. Longfellow.
In an alarmed manner.
Exciting, or calculated to excite, alarm; causing apprehensionof danger; as, an alarming crisis or report.-- A*larm"ing*ly, adv.
One prone to sound or excite alarms, especially, needlessalarms. Macaulay.
See Alarm. [Now Poetic]
Of or pertaining to wings; also, wing-shaped.The alary system of insects. Wollaston.
An exclamation expressive of sorrow, pity, or apprehension ofevil; -- in old writers, sometimes followed by day or white; alas theday, like alack a day, or alas the white.
Lately; of late. [Archaic]There hath been alate such tales spread abroad. Latimer.
The state of being winged.
See Alan. [Obs.] Chaucer.

A vestment of white linen, reaching to the feet, an envelopingthe person; -- in the Roman Catholic church, worn by those in holyorders when officiating at mass. It was formerly worn, at least byclerics, in daily life.
See Albicore.
A white crystalline resinous substance extracted from gutta-percha by the action of alcohol or ether.
Of or pertaining to Albania, a province of Turkey.-- n.
A white metallic alloy; which is made into spoons, forks,teapots, etc. British plate or German silver. See German silver,under German.

A web-footed bird, of the genus Diomedea, of which there areseveral species. They are the largest of sea birds, capable of long-continued flight, and are often seen at great distances from theland. They are found chiefly in the southern hemisphere.
Whiteness. Specifically: (Astron.) The ratio which the lightreflected from an unpolished surface bears to the total light fallingupon that surface.
Even though; although; notwithstanding. Chaucer.Albeit so masked, Madam, I love the truth. Tennyson.
A bituminous mineral resembling asphaltum, found in the countyof A.
A picture printed from a kind of gelatine plate produced bymeans of a photographic negative.
The act of becoming white; whitishness.
Becoming white or whitish; moderately white.
Growing or becoming white.
The process of becoming white, or developing white patches, orstreaks.

A name applied to several large fishes of the Mackerel family,esp. Orcynus alalonga. One species (Orcynus thynnus), common in theMediterranean and Atlantic, is called in New England the horsemackerel; the tunny. [Written also albacore.]
The act or process of making white. [Obs.]
Of or pertaining to the Albigenses.
A female albino. Holmes.
The state or condition of being an albino: abinoism;leucopathy.
Affected with albinism.

A person, whether negro, Indian, or white, in whom by somedefect of organization the substance which gives color to the skin,hair, and eyes is deficient or in a morbid state. An albino has askin of a milky hue, with hair of the same color, and eyes with deepred pupil and pink or blue iris. The term is also used of the loweranimals, as white mice, elephants, etc.; and of plants in a whitishcondition from the absence of chlorophyll. Amer. Cyc.
The state or condition of being an albino; albinism.
Affected with albinism.
An ancient name of England, still retained in poetry.In that nook-shotten isle of Albion. Shak.
A mineral of the feldspar family, triclinic in crystallization,and in composition a silicate of alumina and soda. It is a commonconstituent of granite and of various igneous rocks. See Feldspar.
A kind of plastic cement, or artificial stone, consistingchiefly of magnesia and silica; -- called also albolite.
The imaginary milk-white animal on which Mohammed was said tohave been carried up to heaven; a white mule.
Of the nature of, or resembling, the white of the eye, or of anegg; albuminous; -- a term applied to textures, humors, etc., whichare perfectly white.
Same as Leucoma.
A white tablet on which anything was inscribed, as a list ofnames, etc.

Nourishing matter stored up within the integuments of the seedin many plants, but not incorporated in the embryo. It is the flourypart in corn, wheat, and like grains, the oily part in poppy seeds,the fleshy part in the cocoanut, etc.
To cover or saturate with albumen; to coat or treat with analbuminous solution; as, to albuminize paper.

A thick, viscous nitrogenous substance, which is the chief andcharacteristic constituent of white of eggs and of the serum ofblood, and is found in other animal substances, both fluid and solid,also in many plants. It is soluble in water is coagulated by heat adby certain chemical reagents. Acid albumin, a modification of albuminproduced by the action of dilute acids. It is not coagulated by heat.-- Alkali albumin, albumin as modified by the action of alkalinesubstances; -- called also albuminate.
A substance produced by the action of an alkali upon albumin,and resembling casein in its properties; also, a compound formed bythe union of albumin with another substance.
Supplying albumen.
An instrument for ascertaining the quantity of albumen in aliquid.
The substance of the cells which inclose the white of birds'eggs.
Producing albumin.
Resembling albumin.-- n.
Of the nature of an albuminoid.
A diffusible substance formed from albumin by the action ofnatural or artificial gastric juice. See Peptone.
A morbid condition due to excessive increase of albuminouselements in the blood.
A morbid condition in which albumin is present in the urine.
A compound or class of compounds formed from albumin by diluteacids or by an acid solution of pepsin. Used also in combination, asantialbumose, hemialbumose.
The bleak, a small European fish having scales of a peculiarlysilvery color which are used in making artificial pearls.
Of or pertaining to alburnum; of the alburnum; as, alburnoussubstances.
The white and softer part of wood, between the inner bark andthe hard wood or duramen; sapwood.
Scotland; esp. the Highlands of Scotland. T. Cambell.
Same as Alcaid.
Same as Alkahest.

Pertaining to Alcæus, a lyric poet of Mitylene, about 6000 b.c.-- n. A kind of verse, so called from Alcæus. One variety consistsof five feet, a spondee or iambic, an iambic, a long syllable, andtwo dactyls.
A magistrate or judge in Spain and in Spanish America, etc.Prescott.
The jurisdiction or office of an alcalde; also, the building orchamber in which he conducts the business of his office.
See Alkalimeter.
An oriental shrub (Lawsonia inermis) from which henna isobtained.
A vessel of porous earthenware, used for cooling liquids byevaporation from the exterior surface.
Same as Alcaid.
A fortress; also, a royal palace. Prescott.
A genus of perching birds, including the European kingfisher(Alcedo ispida). See Halcyon.
In the manner of alchemy.
One who practices alchemy.You are alchemist; make gold. Shak.
Alchemy. [Obs.]
To change by alchemy; to transmute. Lovelace.
See Alchemic, Alchemist, Alchemistic, Alchemy.
A small South American dog, domesticated by the aborigines.

A class of compounds analogous to vinic alcohol inconstitution. Chemically speaking, they are hydroxides of certainorganic radicals; as, the radical ethyl forms common or ethyl alcohol(C2H5OH); methyl forms methyl alcohol (CH3.OH) or wood spirit; amylforms amyl alcohol (C5H11.OH) or fusel oil, etc.
A crystallizable compound of a salt with alcohol, in which thelatter plays a part analogous to that of water of crystallization.Graham.
An alcoholic tincture prepared with fresh plants. New Eng.Dict.
Of or pertaining to alcohol, or partaking of its qualities;derived from, or caused by, alcohol; containing alcohol; as,alcoholic mixtures; alcoholic gastritis; alcoholic odor.
A diseased condition of the system, brought about by thecontinued use of alcoholic liquors.

An instrument for determining the strength of spirits, with ascale graduated so as to indicate the percentage of pure alcohol,either by weight or volume. It is usually a form of hydrometer with aspecial scale.
The process or method of ascertaining the proportion of purealcohol which spirituous liquors contain.
The Mohammedan Scriptures; the Koran (now the usual form).[Spelt also Alcoran.]
Of or pertaining to the Koran.
One who adheres to the letter of the Koran, rejecting alltraditions.

The bark of several trees, esp. of Bowdichia virgilioides ofBrazil, used as a remedy for consumption; of Byrsonima crassifolia,used in tanning; of Alchornea latifolia, used medicinally; or ofQuercus ilex, the cork tree.
A recessed portion of a room, or a small room opening into alarger one; especially, a recess to contain a bed; a lateral recessin a library.
See Halcyon.
A group of soft-bodied Alcyonaria, of which Alcyonium is thetype. See Illust. under Alcyonaria.
One of the orders of Anthozoa. It includes the Alcyonacea,Pennatulacea, and Gorgonacea.
The kingfishers.
Of or pertaining to the Alcyonaria.
A genus of fleshy Alcyonaria, its polyps somewhat resemblingflowers with eight fringed rays. The term was also formerly used forcertain species of sponges.
Like or pertaining to the Alcyonaria.-- n.
Continually. [Obs.] Chaucer.

A red star of the first magnitude, situated in the eye ofTaurus; the Bull's Eye. It is the bright star in the group called theHyades.Now when Aldebaran was mounted high Above the shiny Cassiopeia'schair. Spenser.
A colorless, mobile, and very volatile liquid obtained fromalcohol by certain of oxidation.
Of or pertaining to aldehyde; as, aldehydic acid. Miller.

A tree, usually growing in moist land, and belonging to thegenus Alnus. The wood is used by turners, etc.; the bark by dyers andtanners. In the U. S. the species of alder are usually shrubs orsmall trees. Black alder. (a) A European shrub (Rhamnus frangula);Alder buckthorn. (b) An American species of holly (Ilexverticillata), bearing red berries.
The office of an alderman.
Relating to, becoming to, or like, an alderman; characteristicof an alderman.
Like or suited to an alderman.
Pertaining to, or like, an alderman.
The condition, position, or office of an alderman. Fabyan.
Made of alder.
One of a breed of cattle raised in Alderney, one of the ChannelIslands. Alderneys are of a dun or tawny color and are often calledJersey cattle. See Jersey, 3.

An epithet applied to editions (chiefly of the classics) whichproceeded from the press of Aldus Manitius, and his family, ofVenice, for the most part in the 16th century and known by the signof the anchor and the dolphin. The term has also been applied tocertain elegant editions of English works.

A colorless liquid, C4H8O2, obtained by condensation of twomolecules of acetaldehyde: CH3CHO + CH3CHO = H3CH(OH)CH2CO; also, anyof various derivatives of this. The same reaction has been applied,under the name of aldol condensation, to the production of manycompounds.
In a leaking condition.
Depending on some uncertain contingency; as, an aleatorycontract. Bouvier.
A bench in or before an alehouse. Bunyan.
A beverage, formerly made by boiling ale with spice, sugar, andsops of bread.Their aleberries, caudles, possets. Beau. & Fl.
Applied to those ova which segment uniformly, and which havelittle or no food yelk embedded in their protoplasm. Balfour.

Orig., an officer appointed to look to the goodness of ale andbeer; also, one of the officers chosen by the liverymen of London toinspect the measures used in public houses. But the office is asinecure. [Also called aletaster.] [Eng.]
The plant costmary, which was formerly much used for flavoringale.
A group of birds including the common fowl and the pheasants.
Cockfighting.
See Alectryomancy.
Cockfighting.
Divination by means of a cock and grains of corn placed on theletters of the alphabet, the letters being put together in the orderin which the grains were eaten. Amer. Cyc.

On or toward the lee, or the side away from the wind; theopposite of aweather. The helm of a ship is alee when pressed closeto the lee side. Hard alee, or Luff alee, an order to put the helm tothe lee side.
Sour ale; vinegar made of ale. Cecil.
Gay; cheerful; sprightly. [Obs.] Bacon.
To allay or alleviate; to lighten. [Obs.]That shall alegge this bitter blast. Spenser.
Ground ivy (Nepeta Glechoma).
A house where ale is retailed; hence, a tippling house.Macaulay.
The imperial standard of the Turkish Empire.
Belonging to the Alemanni, a confederacy of warlike Germantribes.

An apparatus formerly used in distillation, usually made ofglass or metal. It has mostly given place to the retort and wormstill.Used also metaphorically. The alembic of a great poet's imagination.Brimley.
The salt of wisdom of the alchemists, a double salt composed ofthe chlorides of ammonium and mercury. It was formerly used as astimulant. Brande & C.
At full length; lenghtwise. Chaucer.
Not having scales.-- n.
A pole set up as the sign of an alehouse. [Obs.]

An alarm from a real or threatened attack; a sudden attack;also, a bugle sound to give warning. "We have had an alert." Farrow.On the alert, on the lookout or watch against attack or danger; readyto act.
In an alert manner; nimbly.
The quality of being alert or on the alert; briskness;nimbleness; activity.
A stake or pole projecting from, or set up before, an alehouse,as a sign; an alepole. At the end was commonly suspended a garland, abunch of leaves, or a "bush." [Obs.] Chaucer.
See Aleconner. [Eng.]
The science which treats of the nature of truth and evidence.Sir W. Hamilton.
An instrument for viewing pictures by means of a lens, so as topresent them in their natural proportions and relations.
Divination by means of flour. Encyc. Brit.
An instrument for determining the expansive properties, orquality, of gluten in flour. Knight.
Flour made of aleurone, used as a substitute for ordinary flourin preparing bread for diabetic persons.
An albuminoid substance which occurs in minute grains ("proteingranules") in maturing seeds and tubers; -- supposed to be amodification of protoplasm.
Having the nature of aleurone. D. C. Eaton.
Young fish; fry.
Halloo. [Obs.] Spenser.
A woman who keeps an alehouse. Gay.
Belonging to Alexandria; Alexandrian. Bancroft.
Alexipharmic. [Obs.]
An antidote against poison or infection; a counterpoison.
Serving to drive off fever; antifebrile.-- n.
A preservative against contagious and infectious diseases, andthe effects of poison in general. Brande & C.
The lucern (Medicago sativa); -- so called in California,Texas, etc.
An alloy of nickel and silver electroplated with silver.
An ensign; a standard bearer. [Obs.] J. Fletcher.
A caldron of boiling water into which an accused person plungedhis forearm as a test of innocence or guilt.
The pin grass (Erodium cicutarium), a weed in California.
An edible marine fish of California (Rhacochilus toxotes).
A saddlebag. [Sp. Amer.]
In the open-air. Smollett.
A kind of seaweed; pl. the class of cellular cryptogamic plantswhich includes the black, red, and green seaweeds, as kelp, dulse,sea lettuce, also marine and fresh water confervæ, etc.
Pertaining to, or like, algæ.
A term used for the Powder of Algaroth, a white powder which isa compound of trichloride and trioxide of antimony. It was formerlyused in medicine as an emetic, purgative, and diaphoretic.
The agglutinated seeds and husks of the legumes of a SouthAmerican tree (Inga Marthæ). It is valuable for tanning leather, andas a dye.
The true gazelle.
That branch of mathematics which treats of the relations andproperties of quantity by means of letters and other symbols. It isapplicable to those relations that are true of every kind ofmagnitude.
By algebraic process.
One versed in algebra.
To perform by algebra; to reduce to algebraic form.
Of or pertaining to Algeria.-- n.
Of or pertaining to Algiers or Algeria.
Cold; chilly. Bailey. Algid cholera (Med.), Asiatic cholera.
Chilliness; coldness; especially (Med.),
Algidity. [Obs.]
Producing cold.
A nitrogenous substance resembling gelatin, obtained fromcertain algæ.
Of the nature of, or resembling, an alga.
A fixed star, in Medusa's head, in the constellation Perseus,remarkable for its periodic variation in brightness.
Of or pertaining to algology; as, algological specimens.
One learned about algæ; a student of algology.
The study or science of algæ or seaweeds.

An instrument for measuring sensations of pain due to pressure.It has a piston rod with a blunted tip which is pressed against theskin. -- Al*gom"e*try (#), n. -- Al`go*met"ric (#), *met"ric*al (#),a. --Al`go*met"ric*al*ly, adv.
The Algonkian period or era, or system or group of systems.

Pertaining to or designating the most extensive of thelinguistic families of North American Indians, their territoryformerly including practically all of Canada east of the 115thmeridian and south of Hudson's Bay and the part of the United Stateseast of the Mississippi and north of Tennessee and Virginia, with theexception of the territory occupied by the northern Iroquoian tribes.There are nearly 100,000 Indians of the Algonquian tribes, of whichthe strongest are the Ojibwas (Chippewas), Ottawas, Crees,Algonquins, Micmacs, and Blackfeet. -- n.
Cold; chilliness.
Of or pertaining to the algæ, or seaweeds; abounding with, orlike, seaweed.
An inferior officer of justice in Spain; a warrant officer; aconstable. Prescott.
Same as Almug (and etymologically preferable). 2 Chron. ii. 8.
The palace of the Moorish kings at Granada.
See Henna.

The plea or mode of defense under which a person on trial for acrime proves or attempts to prove that he was in another place whenthe alleged act was committed; as, to set up an alibi; to prove analibi.
Quality of being alible.
Nutritive; nourishing.
A kind of wine, formerly much esteemed; -- said to have beenmade near Alicant, in Spain. J. Fletcher.
